channel.title: Decompiled forms to Netbeans or any formdesigner
channel.description:
Another question maybe be dumb but after I decompiled my project I figured out it's hard to design forms in notepad etc.. really need to somehow import them to netbeans without actually redesigning them by looking at the notepad data.
Plus the data from notepad forms for some reason is much better,shorter by 30 lines then the data netbeans spits out for a simple aboutbox

item.title: Decompiled forms to Netbeans or any formdesigner
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

sometimes null is ok. most of the times i can figure out a way to use nested borderlayouts

Read full topic
item.source: Decompiled forms to Netbeans or any formdesigner

item.title: Decompiled forms to Netbeans or any formdesigner
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:14, topic:337143”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=433553.msg3186829#msg3186829 date=1271826147]

[quote author=Lothy link=topic=433553.msg3186817#msg3186817 date=1271824012]

[quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=433553.msg3185883#msg3185883 date=1271728350]

[quote author=Speljohan link=topic=433553.msg3184674#msg3184674 date=1271614537]

yeah i’ve also used JFormDesigner for a while… 30 day trial ran out just set my computer date back to 2008 and its all functioning again but still it’s a separate app then the code it generates has to be copy/pasted into main project seems like alot of work when everything could be bundle into one project file. Probably going to go with one of those rent a coder websites.
[/quote]There’s a plugin for IntelliJ IDEA that works great. There’s probably one for Eclipse as well.
[/quote]yeah, eclipse’s isn’t particularly bad although i personally just despise automated code from any generator

Why though? No matter how bad the generated code is, I’ll take it if it saves me hours of fiddling unnecessarily when trying to make a GUI.
[/quote]to be honest, the only real pain in the ass in writing a GUI in java is the positioning, which is why i wrote a simple resizable GUI displaying the absolute position (relative to the program’s window) of whatever component im using so that whenever i write an application in java that needs a GUI, i dont have to fiddle around with positioning (since most, if not all of the time, i use a ‘null layout’) - that way i already have the positioning dealt with
[/quote]null layout is shit. Use a decent layoutmanager instead. Such a waste of time to write a bunch of useless code just for window resizing when it can be automated.[/quote]I can’t always seem to be able to accommodate the exact desired position of multiple components using a predefined layout, I’d have to go ahead and use a combination of multiple which requires more of a hierarchical oriented design for the actual parent components; and even then when you finally manage to get the standard positioning working as desired, the topmost parent components can’t actually draw anything since it is overridden by the seemingly abstract occupancy of its child-component’s position (this usually happens with borderlayouts).

I try to avoid using awt/swing as much as possible and usually make my own (lightweight) component implementations to fit my application’s design…/jagex

Read full topic

yeah i’ve also used JFormDesigner for a while… 30 day trial ran out just set my computer date back to 2008 and its all functioning again but still it’s a separate app then the code it generates has to be copy/pasted into main project seems like alot of work when everything could be bundle into one project file. Probably going to go with one of those rent a coder websites.
[/quote]There’s a plugin for IntelliJ IDEA that works great. There’s probably one for Eclipse as well.
[/quote]yeah, eclipse’s isn’t particularly bad although i personally just despise automated code from any generator

Why though? No matter how bad the generated code is, I’ll take it if it saves me hours of fiddling unnecessarily when trying to make a GUI.
[/quote]to be honest, the only real pain in the ass in writing a GUI in java is the positioning, which is why i wrote a simple resizable GUI displaying the absolute position (relative to the program’s window) of whatever component im using so that whenever i write an application in java that needs a GUI, i dont have to fiddle around with positioning (since most, if not all of the time, i use a ‘null layout’) - that way i already have the positioning dealt with[/quote]null layout is shit. Use a decent layoutmanager instead. Such a waste of time to write a bunch of useless code just for window resizing when it can be automated.
